stem: Refer to the drawing of a section of 6-inch diameter pipe containing subcooled water flowing from left to right at 100 gpm (see figure below). The pipe is frictionless and no heat transfer is occurring. Point B is 10 feet higher in elevation than point A. How does the enthalpy of the water at point A compare to point B? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: The enthalpy of the water at point A is smaller, because some of the water’s kinetic energy is converted to enthalpy as it flows to point B.
choices.B: The enthalpy of the water at point A is greater, because some of the water’s enthalpy is converted to potential energy as it flows to point B.
choices.C: The enthalpy of the water at points A and B is the same, because the pipe is frictionless and no heat transfer is occurring.
choices.D: The enthalpy of the water at points A and B is the same, because the total energy of the water does not change from point A to point B. -839- PWR Test Items

stem: For which of the following ideal processes, if any, is the fluid outlet enthalpy greater than the fluid inlet enthalpy? (Assume horizontal fluid flow in each process.) (A) Cooling water flowing through a fixed convergent nozzle. (B) Cooling water flowing through an operating lube oil heat exchanger. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020
